meanings.def: a liquid without colour, smell or taste that falls as rain, is in lakes, rivers and seas, and is used for drinking, washing, etc.
examples: a glass of water
drinking water
There is hot and cold running water (= water supplied by pipes) in all the bedrooms.
The refugees are desperate for food, clean water and medical supplies.
All chickens need a continuous supply of fresh water to drink.
water pollution
water shortages
concerns about water quality
The water (= the supply of water) was turned off for several hours each day during the drought.
Alexis filled the sink with soapy water.
As the weather heats up, water evaporates.
Avoid drinking the tap water when you first arrive in the country.
Brown water gushed out of the rusty old tap.
Cook the pasta in plenty of boiling salted water.
Don't slosh too much water on the floor when you're having a bath.
He twisted it to drain the excess water.
How do you pump the water up here?
I could feel the icy water entering my lungs.
She dried off the excess water from her hair.
Some fields have areas with standing water.
That causes the moss to absorb water.
The burst pipe was spurting water everywhere.
The farmers draw their irrigation water from the Colorado.
The surface water made the road treacherous for drivers.
There was water dripping from a hole in the ceiling.
They turned the water off for a few hours to do some work on the pipes.
Water got into the boat and was sloshing around under our feet.
a woman fetching water
areas which are dependent on ground water
household water heaters
the fast-flowing water of the river
the purest well water
the region's most important fresh water source
They climbed a tree to escape the rising water.
The water is now receding after the floods.
The water was rising fast.
A pesticide that dissolves in water can move with water in the soil.
Wash the skin thoroughly with soap and warm water.
The site had no electricity or water.
They survived for two days without food or water.
a water treatment plant
The children were all told to bring a bottle of water.
a water bottle
A water molecule can be split into hydrogen and oxygen atoms.
water vapour
the impact of agriculture on the region's water resources
Any excess water is left in the water tank.
Trout cannot survive in ponds where water temperatures exceed 75 degrees.
She took the teacup and poured the water onto the floor.

meanings.def: an area of water, especially a lake, river, sea or ocean
examples: We walked down to the water's edge.
shallow/deep water
in the water It was lovely and cool in the water.
She fell into the water.
In the lagoon the water was calm.
She crouched at the water's edge to wash her hands.
The boat cut effortlessly through the water.
large expanses of open water
Swans glided across the water.

meanings.def: the surface of a mass of water
examples: on the water The leaves floated on the water.
in the water I could see my reflection in the water.
under the water She dived under the water.
He disappeared under the water.
I saw something large floating in the water.
An abandoned town lies under the water of the reservoir.
The swan landed gracefully on the water.
Try to keep your head above the water.

meanings.def: the water in a particular lake, river, sea or ocean
examples: the grey waters of the River Clyde
This species is found in coastal waters around the Indian Ocean.
At last the boat reached safer waters.
inland navigable waters
the calm waters of Lake Como
the freezing waters of the Irish Sea
the icy waters of the North Atlantic
the shark-infested waters off the coast of Florida
The ship had drifted into uncharted waters.

meanings.def: an area of sea or ocean belonging to a particular country
examples: in… waters We were still in British waters.
fishing in international waters
The submarine had strayed into Russian waters.

meanings.def: used to describe a situation, usually one that is difficult, dangerous or not familiar
examples: The conversation got into the murky waters of jealousy and relationships.
The government has warned of stormy waters ahead.
I was going into uncharted waters.

meanings.def: to be in or get into trouble
family relationships are stronger than any others
to destroy somebody/something completely
to show that somebody/something is not good by being very much better than it/them
examples: I like my old phone, but this new model blows it out of the water.

meanings.def: using a boat or ship
examples: They reached Naples by water.
Goods were often transported by water in the 19th century.

meanings.def: a complete difference or division between two people or groups
examples: Voters want to see clear blue water between the main parties.
They failed to put clear blue water between themselves and their competitors.

meanings.def: a person or plan that is dead in the water has failed and has little hope of succeeding in the future
examples: His leadership campaign is dead in the water.

meanings.def: to start doing something very carefully to see if it will be successful or not
examples: We decided to dip a toe in the computer games market.

meanings.def: a person who feels uncomfortable because he or she is in an environment that is not familiar
despite any difficulties
examples: I was determined to go, come hell or high water.

meanings.def: in trouble or difficulty
used to say that something happened in the past and is now forgotten or no longer important
to deal with a difficult situation, especially one in which you have financial problems, and just manage to survive
examples: I’m not sure how much longer we’ll be able to keep our heads above water.

meanings.def: (to become used to something) very easily, without any problems or fears
examples: She has taken to teaching like a duck to water.

meanings.def: in large quantities
examples: He spends money like water.

meanings.def: if an argument, an excuse, a theory, etc. does not hold water, you cannot believe it
to urinate
to give reasons for not being in favour of something; to criticize something
examples: She immediately poured cold water on his plans to expand the business.

meanings.def: to try to settle an argument
a person who seems to be quiet or shy may surprise you by knowing a lot or having deep feelings
to find out what the situation is before doing something or making a decision
to keep yourself in the same place in deep water by moving your arms and legs
to make no progress while you are waiting for something to happen
examples: I decided to tread water until a better job came along.

meanings.def: used to say that something, especially criticism, has no effect on somebody/something
examples: I can't tell my son what to do; it's water off a duck's back with him.

meanings.def: when a pregnant woman’s waters break, the liquid in her womb passes out of her body just before the baby is born
you can give somebody the opportunity to do something, but you cannot force them to do it if they do not want to

idioms.def: to be in or get into trouble
family relationships are stronger than any others

idioms.idiom: blow somebody/something out of the water
idioms.def: to destroy somebody/something completely
examples: I like my old phone, but this new model blows it out of the water.

idioms.def: using a boat or ship
examples: They reached Naples by water.
Goods were often transported by water in the 19th century.

idioms.idiom: clear blue water (between A and B)
idioms.def: a complete difference or division between two people or groups
examples: Voters want to see clear blue water between the main parties.
They failed to put clear blue water between themselves and their competitors.

idioms.def: a person or plan that is dead in the water has failed and has little hope of succeeding in the future
examples: His leadership campaign is dead in the water.

idioms.idiom: dip a toe in/into something | dip a toe in/into the water
idioms.def: to start doing something very carefully to see if it will be successful or not
examples: We decided to dip a toe in the computer games market.

idioms.def: a person who feels uncomfortable because he or she is in an environment that is not familiar
despite any difficulties
examples: I was determined to go, come hell or high water.

idioms.def: in trouble or difficulty
used to say that something happened in the past and is now forgotten or no longer important
to deal with a difficult situation, especially one in which you have financial problems, and just manage to survive
examples: I’m not sure how much longer we’ll be able to keep our heads above water.

idioms.idiom: (take to something) like a duck to water
idioms.def: (to become used to something) very easily, without any problems or fears
examples: She has taken to teaching like a duck to water.

idioms.def: in large quantities
examples: He spends money like water.

idioms.def: if an argument, an excuse, a theory, etc. does not hold water, you cannot believe it
to urinate
to give reasons for not being in favour of something; to criticize something
examples: She immediately poured cold water on his plans to expand the business.

idioms.def: to try to settle an argument
a person who seems to be quiet or shy may surprise you by knowing a lot or having deep feelings
to find out what the situation is before doing something or making a decision
to keep yourself in the same place in deep water by moving your arms and legs
examples: I decided to tread water until a better job came along.

idioms.def: used to say that something, especially criticism, has no effect on somebody/something
examples: I can't tell my son what to do; it's water off a duck's back with him.

idioms.def: when a pregnant woman’s waters break, the liquid in her womb passes out of her body just before the baby is born

idioms.idiom: you can lead/take a horse to water, but you can’t make it drink
idioms.def: you can give somebody the opportunity to do something, but you cannot force them to do it if they do not want to

meanings.def: to pour water on plants, etc.
examples: to water the plants/garden
Keep the area well watered.
The roses need watering.
Water your houseplants well before you go on holiday.

meanings.def: to become full of tears
examples: The smoke made my eyes water.

meanings.def: to produce saliva
examples: The smells from the kitchen made our mouths water.
The smell of the meat made her mouth water.

meanings.def: to give water to an animal to drink
examples: to water the horses
(humorous) After a tour of the grounds, the guests were fed and watered.

meanings.def: to provide an area of land with water
examples: be watered by something The valley is watered by a stream.

meanings.def: to add water to an alcoholic drink
examples: watered wine
